metadata.title: Figure 1 Virucidal activity of WHO formulations I (85 % ethanol) and II (75 % 2-propanol) against SARS-CoV-2. WHO formulations I (A) and II (B) were tested for their efficacy in inactivating SARS-CoV-2. The concentrations of the WHO formulations ranged from 0 % to Efficient inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 by WHO-recommended hand rub 1 formulations and alcohols 2

abstract.text: 80 % with an exposure time of 30 seconds. Viral titers are displayed as 50 % tissue culture infectious dose 50 (TCID 50 /mL) values. Cytotoxic effects are displayed as dashed bars are and were calculated analogous to virus infectivity. RFs are included above the bar. The mean of two -three independent experiments with standard deviation are shown. LLOQ: lower limit of quantification. Top inserts: Regression analysis of the inactivation of SARS-CoV-2, bovine CoV (BCoV), SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV by WHO formulation I (A) and II (B). Depicted is the percentage of inactivation at different concentrations.

It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020. 03 The recent emergence of Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-2 CoV-2) causing COVID-19 is a major burden for health care systems worldwide. It is 3 important to address if the current infection control instructions based on active 4 ingredients are sufficient. We therefore determined the virucidal activity of two 5 alcohol-based hand rub solutions for hand disinfection recommended by the World 6
Health Organization (WHO), as well as commercially available alcohols. Efficient 7 SARS-CoV-2 inactivation was demonstrated for all tested alcohol-based disinfectants. 8

These findings show the successful inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 for the first time and 9 provide confidence in its use for the control of COVID-19. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.986711 doi: bioRxiv preprint 4 especially in the elderly or patients with comorbidities 4 . As of March 6 th 2020 there are 1 101604 globally confirmed cases and related 3460 deaths 5 . Health care experts suspect 2 that a global pandemic is inevitable mainly because human-to-human transmission of 3 SARS-CoV-2 is very efficient and infected individuals can transmit the virus without 4 or with only mild symptoms 4 . Given that so far, no therapeutics or vaccines are 5 available, virus containment and prevention of infection are of highest priority. 6
Effective hand hygiene is crucial to limit virus spread. Therefore, easily available but 7 efficient disinfectants are crucial. The World Health Organization's 'Guidelines for 8

Hand Hygiene in Health Care' suggests two alcohol-based formulations for hand 9 sanitization to reduce pathogen infectivity and spreading. These recommendations are 10 based on fast-acting and broad-spectrum of microbicidal activity, as well as easy 11 accessibility and safety 3 . We have previously shown that WHO formulation I and II 12 were able to inactivate the closely related SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV 6 Results 20 SARS-CoV-2 was highly susceptible to the WHO formulations (Fig. 1) . WHO 21 formulation I, based on 85 % ethanol, efficiently inactivated the virus with reduction 22 factors (RFs) of  5.9 and concentrations between 40 % -80 % (Fig. 1A) . Subsequent 23 regression analysis revealed similar inactivation profiles compared to SARS-CoV, 24 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.986711 doi: bioRxiv preprint 1 pathogenic human CoVs (Fig. 1A) . WHO formulation II, which is based on 75 % 2 isopropanol, demonstrated a better virucidal effect at low concentrations, with 3 complete viral inactivation and RFs of  5 at a minimal concentration of 30 % (Fig.  4   1B) . The regression analysis showed an inactivation profile of SARS-CoV-2, which 5 was in between SARS-CoV, BCoV and MERS-CoV (Fig. 1B) . 6

Next, we addressed the susceptibility of SARS-CoV-2 against the individual 7 components of the WHO recommended formulations which are also the main 8 ingredients of commercially available hand disinfections. Both alcohols, ethanol (Fig.  9 2A) and 2-propanol ( Fig. 2B) were able to reduce viral titers in 30 s exposure to 10 background levels with RFs between  4.8 and 5.9 after 30 sec. Furthermore, we could 11

show that a minimal concentration of 30 % ethanol or 2-propanol is sufficient for viral 12 inactivation (Fig. 2) . The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.986711 doi: bioRxiv preprint

FIGREF0.text: of alcohols on SARS-CoV-2. Commercially available ethanol (A), or 2-propanol (B) were tested for their efficacy in inactivating SARS-CoV-2. The biocide concentrations ranged from 0 % to 80 % with an exposure time of 30 seconds. Viral titers are displayed as 50 % tissue culture infectious dose 50 (TCID 50 /mL) values. Cytotoxic effects are displayed as dashed bars are and were calculated analogous to virus infectivity. LLOQ: lower limit of quantification. RFs are included above the bar. Dashed line: limit of detection. The mean of two -three independent experiments with standard deviation are shown.

FIGREF2.text: COVID-19 outbreak puts a huge burden on the world's health care 13 systems. Without effective therapeutics or vaccines being available, effective hygiene 14 measure are of utmost importance to prevent viral spreading. It is therefore crucial to 15 evaluate current infection control strategies against SARS-CoV-2. We show the 16 inactivation of the novel coronavirus for the first time and endorse the importance of 17 disinfectant-based hand hygiene to reduce SARS-CoV-2 transmission. 18 19 Introduction 20 SARS-CoV-2 is the third highly pathogenic human CoV to have crossed the species 21 barrier into humans during the last 20 years 1,2,3 . SARS-CoV-2 infection is associated 22 with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) which is characterized by severe 23 respiratory distress, fever and cough, leading to a high percentage of fatalities, 24

FIGREF3.text: inactivate SARS-CoV-2 were only translated from findings with 14 other coronaviruses 7 . To evaluate if alcohol-based disinfectants are also efficient for 15 the inactivation of SARS-CoV-2, we tested different concentrations of WHO 16 formulation I and II, as well as the alcohols ethanol and 2-propanol for their

FIGREF4.text: shows that SARS-CoV-2 can be efficiently inactivated by both WHO 16 formulations implicating their use in health care systems and viral outbreak situations. 17 Notably, both tested alcohols, ethanol and 2-propanol were efficient in inactivating the 18 virus in 30 s at a minimal final concentration of at least 30 %. Alcohol constitutes the 19 basis for many hand rubs routinely used in health care settings. Our findings are 20 therefore of utmost importance in the current outbreak situation to minimize (v/v). The isopropyl-based formulation, WHO II, contains 75 % 10 isopropanol (w/w), 0.725 % glycerol (v/v) and 0.125 % hydrogen peroxide (v/v) 8 . In 11 addition, ethanol (CAS 64-17-5), and 2-propanol (CAS 67-63-0) were investigated. 12 Quantitative Suspension Test and Virus Titration 13 Virucidal activity studies were performed with a quantitative suspension test with 30 14 seconds exposure time 3 . Briefly, one part virus suspension was mixed with one part 15 organic load (0.3 % bovine serum albumin [BSA] as interfering substance) and eight 16 parts disinfection solution of different concentrations. Following 30 seconds exposure, 17 samples were serially diluted and the TCID 50 /mL values were determined by crystal 18 violet staining and subsequent scoring the amounts of wells displaying cytopathic 19 effects. TCID 50 is calculated by the Spearman & Kärber algorithm as described 9 . 20 Cytotoxic effects of disinfectants were monitored by crystal violet staining and optical 21 analysis for altered density and morphology of the cellular monolayer in the absence of 22 virus and were quantified analogous to the TCID 50 /mL of the virus infectivity.

FIGREF5.text: Virucidal activity of WHO formulations I (85 % ethanol) and II (75 % 2-3 propanol) against SARS-CoV-2. WHO formulations I (A) and II (B) were tested for 4 their efficacy in inactivating SARS-CoV-2. The concentrations of the WHO 5 formulations ranged from 0 % to 80 % with an exposure time of 30 seconds. Viral 6 titers are displayed as 50 % tissue culture infectious dose 50 (TCID 50 /mL) values. 7 Cytotoxic effects are displayed as dashed bars are and were calculated analogous to 8 virus infectivity. RFs are included above the bar. The mean of two -three independent 9 experiments with standard deviation are shown. LLOQ: lower limit of quantification. 10 Top inserts: Regression analysis of the inactivation of SARS-CoV-2, bovine CoV 11 (BCoV), SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV by WHO formulation I (A) and II (B).
